declarations.comments: A value-level proxy for a type-level symbol.
declarations.title: SProxy

declarations.comments: Proxy for a `Functor`.
declarations.title: FProxy

declarations.comments:
Inject into the variant at a given label.
```purescript
maybeAtFoo :: forall r. VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe | r) Int
maybeAtFoo = inj (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (Just 42)
```
declarations.title: inj

declarations.comments:
Attempt to read a variant at a given label.
```purescript
case prj (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") maybeAtFoo of
  Just (Just i) -> i + 1
  _ -> 0
```
declarations.title: prj

declarations.comments:
Attempt to read a variant at a given label by providing branches.
The failure branch receives the provided variant, but with the label
removed.
declarations.title: on

declarations.comments:
Match a `VariantF` with a `Record` containing functions for handling cases.
This is similar to `on`, except instead of providing a single label and
handler, you can provide a record where each field maps to a particular
`VariantF` case.

```purescript
onMatch
 { foo: \foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" id foo
 , bar: \bar -> "Bar: " <> snd bar
 }
```

Polymorphic functions in records (such as `show` or `id`) can lead
to inference issues if not all polymorphic variables are specified
in usage. When in doubt, label methods with specific types, such as
`show :: Int -> String`, or give the whole record an appropriate type.
declarations.title: onMatch

declarations.comments:
Combinator for exhaustive pattern matching.
```purescript
caseFn :: VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe, bar :: FProxy (Tuple String), baz :: FProxy (Either String)) Int -> String
caseFn = case_
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (\foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" show foo)
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "bar") (\bar -> "Bar: " <> show (snd bar))
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "baz") (\baz -> "Baz: " <> either id show baz)
```
declarations.title: case_

declarations.comments:
Combinator for exhaustive pattern matching using an `onMatch` case record.
```purescript
matchFn :: VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe, bar :: FProxy (Tuple String), baz :: FProxy (Either String)) Int -> String
matchFn = match
 { foo: \foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" show foo
 , bar: \bar -> "Bar: " <> show (snd bar)
 , baz: \baz -> "Baz: " <> either id show baz
 }
```
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments:
Combinator for partial matching with a default value in case of failure.
```purescript
caseFn :: forall r. VariantF (foo :: FProxy Maybe, bar :: FProxy (Tuple String) | r) Int -> String
caseFn = default "No match"
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (\foo -> "Foo: " <> maybe "nothing" show foo)
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "bar") (\bar -> "Bar: " <> show (snd bar))
```
declarations.title: default

declarations.comments:
Every `VariantF lt a` can be cast to some `VariantF gt a` as long as `lt` is a
subset of `gt`.
declarations.title: expand

declarations.comments:
A `VariantF gt a` can be cast to some `VariantF lt a`, where `lt` is is a subset
of `gt`, as long as there is proof that the `VariantF`'s runtime tag is
within the subset of `lt`.
declarations.title: contract

declarations.comments:
A low-level eliminator which reifies the `IsSymbol`, `Cons` and
`Functor` constraints require to reconstruct the Variant. This
lets you work generically with some VariantF at runtime.
declarations.title: unvariantF

declarations.comments: Reconstructs a VariantF given an UnvariantF eliminator.
declarations.title: revariantF

declarations.comments: A value-level proxy for a type-level symbol.
declarations.title: SProxy

declarations.comments:
Inject into the variant at a given label.
```purescript
intAtFoo :: forall r. Variant (foo :: Int | r)
intAtFoo = inj (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") 42
```
declarations.title: inj

declarations.comments:
Attempt to read a variant at a given label.
```purescript
case prj (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") intAtFoo of
  Just i  -> i + 1
  Nothing -> 0
```
declarations.title: prj

declarations.comments:
Attempt to read a variant at a given label by providing branches.
The failure branch receives the provided variant, but with the label
removed.
declarations.title: on

declarations.comments:
Match a `Variant` with a `Record` containing functions for handling cases.
This is similar to `on`, except instead of providing a single label and
handler, you can provide a record where each field maps to a particular
`Variant` case.

```purescript
onMatch
  { foo: \foo -> "Foo: " <> foo
  , bar: \bar -> "Bar: " <> bar
  }
````

Polymorphic functions in records (such as `show` or `id`) can lead
to inference issues if not all polymorphic variables are specified
in usage. When in doubt, label methods with specific types, such as
`show :: Int -> String`, or give the whole record an appropriate type.
declarations.title: onMatch

declarations.comments:
Combinator for exhaustive pattern matching.
```purescript
caseFn :: Variant (foo :: Int, bar :: String, baz :: Boolean) -> String
caseFn = case_
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (\foo -> "Foo: " <> show foo)
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "bar") (\bar -> "Bar: " <> bar)
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "baz") (\baz -> "Baz: " <> show baz)
```
declarations.title: case_

declarations.comments:
Combinator for exhaustive pattern matching using an `onMatch` case record.
```purescript
matchFn :: Variant (foo :: Int, bar :: String, baz :: Boolean) -> String
matchFn = match
  { foo: \foo -> "Foo: " <> show foo
  , bar: \bar -> "Bar: " <> bar
  , baz: \baz -> "Baz: " <> show baz
  }
```
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments:
Combinator for partial matching with a default value in case of failure.
```purescript
caseFn :: forall r. Variant (foo :: Int, bar :: String | r) -> String
caseFn = default "No match"
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "foo") (\foo -> "Foo: " <> show foo)
 # on (SProxy :: SProxy "bar") (\bar -> "Bar: " <> bar)
```
declarations.title: default

declarations.comments:
Every `Variant lt` can be cast to some `Variant gt` as long as `lt` is a
subset of `gt`.
declarations.title: expand

declarations.comments:
A `Variant gt` can be cast to some `Variant lt`, where `lt` is is a subset
of `gt`, as long as there is proof that the `Variant`'s runtime tag is
within the subset of `lt`.
declarations.title: contract

declarations.comments:
A low-level eliminator which reifies the `IsSymbol` and `Cons`
constraints required to reconstruct the Variant. This lets you
work generically with some Variant at runtime.
declarations.title: unvariant

declarations.comments: Reconstructs a Variant given an Unvariant eliminator.
declarations.title: revariant

declarations.comments: Checks if a record has a key, using a string for the key.
declarations.title: unsafeHas

declarations.comments:
Unsafely gets a value from a record, using a string for the key.

If the key does not exist this will cause a runtime error elsewhere.
declarations.title: unsafeGet

declarations.comments: Proxy for a `Functor`.
declarations.title: FProxy

declarations.comments:
A specialized lookup function which bails early. Foldable's `elem`
is always worst-case.
declarations.title: lookupTag
